The senior election was held last
Monday at one o'clock in Room I I.
C. Leland Getz was elected president, J. Earle Uhler, vice-president;. Abel Wolman, secretary, and
George E. W. Hardy, treasurer.
George M. Gillett, who was president of the junior class last year,
became sergeant-at-arms by virtue
of this fact. John S.'Dickinson
was unanimously re-elected to the
Student Council.
The vote was as follows:
For President—Getz, 19; Niles,
5; Sattler, 3; Sears, 1.
For \Tice-President—Uhler, i8;
Pieper, ii.
For Secretary — \\Tolman,
;
Meekins, 7; Carter, 3.
For Treasurer—Hardy, ; Sattler, 7.
Before the election a motion was
carried providing- that no remarks
should be made upon the nominees.
Julian D. Sears, editor of the
1913 Hullabaloo, made a speech,
pointing out that the success of the
book depended upon whether the
members of the class got to work
or not in securing advertisements.
His appeal was supported by J. E.
Richardson, the Hullabaloo's business manager. Edmond Donoho
explained a plan now employed at
Princeton, whereby all seniors who
wish to compete for the office of
cheer-leader are given an opportunity at the first games to lead the
cheering in some section of the
grandstand, the one who is most
successful being accorded the office.

One of the most famous chemists
in the world, Sir William Ramsay,
is expected to be in Baltimore next
week as the guest of Dr. and Mrs.
Remsen. Lady Ramsay is to accompany her husband. Sir William and Lady Ramsay have been
in Houston, Texas, where they attended the opening of Rice Institute. There he delivered several
lectures in connection with the exercises. Dr. Remsen and Sir William are life-long friends, having
met forty years ago at Tubingen
University, Germany. Sir William
was then a student in chemistry,
and Dr. Remsen was an assistant.
The President has entertained Sir
William in this country before, but
never in Baltimore.
To every student in chemistry,
Sir William Ramsay is a name to
conjure with. It was he who discovered the rarer gases of the
atmosphere ; who discovered helium
'in minerals, before known only to
exist in the atmosphere of the sun.
With the aid of another chemist,
he has shown that radium is transformed partially spontaneously into
helium. Sir William is one of the
recipients of the Nobel prize.
An honorary member of the
Royal Academies of Ireland, Berlin, Bohemia, Holland, Rome, St.
Petersburg, Turin, Roumania, Vienna, Norway and Sweden, Sir
William was created knight in 1902
for his chemical discoveries.
Friday afternoon at three o'clock
Sir William will receive the honorary degree of LL.D. from this University. The facultS7 will attend in
gowns, but this is as far as the
formality of the occasion will go.
Invitations to the ceremony will
be sent to the chemists of this city,
and to the members of the American Chemical Society in Washington. President Remsen has expressed the wish that there may
be a large number of students at
the exercises. This being a rare
opportunity to see one of the great
chemists of the world, every student who can possibly, do so, should
not fail to be present. After the
conferring of the degree, President
and Mrs. Remsen will give a small
reception at their home on Monument street in honor of their distinguished guests.

Junior Class Meeting.

Acting in accordance with the
directions of the Student Council,
the class of 1914 held its first meeting in Room i r, McCoy Hall, at
one o'clock, on Tuesday, October
8. Quite a number seemed to have
been "awed into absence" by the
stand of the Student Council, for
only a bare majority of the class
attended the meeting, President
Hollyday himself being among the
absentees.
H. E. Catlin called the meeting
to order and presided. Officers for
the present school year were elected
as follows:
President—S. D. White.
Vice-President—H. E. Corner.
Secretary - Treasurer — Cochran

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER

1916 Has Its First Meeting.

Around and About.

Lnder the direction of the Student Council the freshman class
held a meeting in Room 12 last
Wednesday to elect officers. Although in years past freshmen
were never left unmolested when
they endeavored to hold meetings
in McCoy Hall, the recently formed
body of student representatives had
the situation fully in hand this year
and no attempts were made to
"break up" the meeting.
President Short of the sophomore class stated officially before
the election took place that the
members of his class would make
no efforts to disturb it.
About forty-five freshmen were
present at the meeting. Although
this is a small number, considering
the total membership of the class, it
is a greater proportion of the total
membership than was the case
when new men had to run up and
down blind alleys to find a suitable
back yard in which to hold their
meetings.
The officers elected were:
President, Primrose; vice-president, Bagley; secretary, Tingley;
treasurer, Nelson; sergeant - at arms, Hall.
The representative of 1916 for
the Student Council is George
Penniman. .
J. S. Dickinson of the Student
Council presided.

This week, night football practice begins under the acetylene
lights. Laboratories keep so many
men in town late that the only way
to make up for the time lost is to
use the giant reflectors.
Ninety - four men are taking
Physics I under Prof. Ames. Some
of the increase is due to the "tech"
men, many of whom are required
to take the course in their freshman year.
Dirt is being moved to enlarge
the new practice field at Homewood. This ground, which lies between Hopkins Field and Charles
Street avenue, is not expected to
have sufficient turf surface for playing until next fall. All teams will
use it in practice.
Dr. Greene got there first!- The
large new apartment house almost
opposite Homewood on University
Parkway is called "Canterbury.

6
Changes in 1912 Football Rules.

First—Playing field, formerly
yards in length, is shortened to an
even loo yards. This change in
itself is not vital, but is made in
order to make possible on small
grounds an extension on territory
in which the forward pass may be
used.
Second—A zone of 10 yards
width beyond the goal lines is established. The purpose of this is
to provide ample space for execution of the forward pass, and scoring on a pass made across the goal
line into this zone is permitted.
Third—The number of downs to
gain to yards is increased from
three to four.
Fourth—The value of touchdowns in increased from five to
six points, the goal from touchdowns and other scores standing
as at present.
Fifth—The 20-yard zone, in
which the former rules provided restrictions to interfere with the forward pass, is eliminated so that the
restrictions will apply now to any
part of the field.
Sixth—After a touch-back the
ball will be put in play from the
20-yard line instead of the 25-yard
line
Seventh—On a kick-off, the ball
instead of being put in play from
the center of the field, will be kicked
from the 4o-yard line of the team
kicking off. Taking into consideration the shortening of the field and
this change in the rules, the kick
is lengthened by 5 yards.
Eighth—The field judge is eliminated; the head linesman will hereafter keep time and be judge of
the official plays in the line of scrimmage.
Ninth—The number of men allowed on the side lines, formerly
three, is reduced to one for each
team.
Tenth—Provision is made that a
bouncing ball cannot score a legitimate goal.
Eleventh—The interval between
the first and second and the third
and fourth periods is reduced from
two minutes to one minute. .

Prof. W. B. Clark went as a delegate from the University to the
two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the Royal Society in London. King George, honorary president, received the delegates and later
entertained them at Windsor. At the
closing meeting in Westminster
Abbey, speeches were made by the
Prime Minister, Lord Morley, and
the Archbishop of Canterbury. The
Royal Society is the parent from
which all other scientific societies
have sprung. This two hundred
and fiftieth anniversary was attended by the foremost scientific men
a n d educators throughout t h e
world. Many college presidents
from this country were delegates—
notably the presidents of II7trvard,
Princeton and Yale.

Satutday's Games.

Of the teams which Hopkins
meets the remainder of the season,
Swarthmore seems to be most formidable. 'Swarthmore beat Pennsylvania Saturday, 6 to 3, in a
game which left no doubt as to its
decisiveness. A week ago Swarthmore won from Lafayette by a
score of 30 to o; and Lafayette
held Yale down to 16 points Saturday. Swarthmore's strength, thus
compared with that of two great
football concerns, shows tip well.
The 'Varsity games with Swarthmore comes in two weeks, and
something must be done!
St. John's defeated the heavy
F. and M. team last week, but not
very much can be learned of their
team, save that it is of tremendous
weight. Saturday will be the first
time Hopkins has met this college.
On two occasions Stevens has
made poor showings this season.
Both Princeton and the Army won
from her by scores as large as 30
points. The scores of 2 to 0, reversed, respectively for the last
two years, bid fair to change their
aspect this fall, and we may look
for a decisive score at Homewood.
St. John's and Dickinson battled
to a 6 to 6 score on Saturday, in
a.game which showed little skill on
either side. St. John's still employs her fake kicks, and forward
Passes to men lurking on the side
lines, and there is a report that
they have a fair team.
Western Maryland characterized
her game with Washington College
by lack of offensive ability. Furthermore, Washington played well
and won, 13 to o.

Omar Picks Up An Acquaintance

Came shining through the dusk an Angel Shape
That called back softly, "Oh, you Santa Claus!"
He smashed a Record as he broke the Tape!
He lit an Omar, saying, "You're some Houri!"
"Some Persian Kitten, if I am the Jury!"
"Whence do you come?" She laughed and closed
one Eye,
"Old Sport, I'll tell you straight—I'm from Missouri!"

LUCAS BROTHERS

The second meeting of the Arbitration Literary Society, which was
held last Thursday in the Donovan
Room, was addressed by Mr. J. T.
O'Neill, for several years police
justice in the Eastern District of
the city. The spontaneous applause
which greeted him after he had
finished his talk showed that he had
deeply impressed every man who
heard him. Although toward the
close of his speech he was very
serious, calling on Hopkins men to
keep the "peanut politician" from
obstructing the course of justice,
and urging them to give a helping
hand to .all persons in trouble, the
main body of his speech was illuminated by true Irish wit. He made
no attempt to philosophize, but
simply told of his experiences during the three years he was a justice,
when he handed out justice to
15,030 men, women and children,
belonging to 26 different nationalities. Of these 15,000 he dismissed
8,000, because he believed that in
each case the criminals were penitent. One Jell, in listening to Mr.
O'Neill, that if there was any man
in the world who could make the
hardest criminal repent, it was he.
One of the funniest stories the
Justice told was about a man who
wanted to get a divorce from his
wife because she would not serve
him with soup. He called the wife,
who was in Court with her husband, aside and told her to give the
man soup every day until further
notice. He then sent the couple
away telling the husband to report
every Sun-day how he was getting
along. The first Sunday the man
came in rubbing his hands and said,
delightedly: "Well, Judge, I've had
my soup—had it every day last
week." The next week, when he
came in, he said : "I've had my soup
this week," to which Justice O'Neill
replied, "I'm mighty glad of that."
The third week the man came in
and said: "Good Lord, can't you
make that woman stop giving me
soup?" The Justice then notified
the wife to stop the soup diet, and
the couple lived happily ever after.

The senior election was held last
Monday at one o'clock in Room I I.
C. Leland Getz was elected president, J. Earle Uhler, vice-president;. Abel Wolman, secretary, and
George E. W. Hardy, treasurer.
George M. Gillett, who was president of the junior class last year,
became sergeant-at-arms by virtue
of this fact. John S.'Dickinson
was unanimously re-elected to the
Student Council.
The vote was as follows:
For President—Getz, 19; Niles,
5; Sattler, 3; Sears, 1.
For \Tice-President—Uhler, i8;
Pieper, ii.
For Secretary — \\Tolman,
;
Meekins, 7; Carter, 3.
For Treasurer—Hardy, ; Sattler, 7.
Before the election a motion was
carried providing- that no remarks
should be made upon the nominees.
Julian D. Sears, editor of the
1913 Hullabaloo, made a speech,
pointing out that the success of the
book depended upon whether the
members of the class got to work
or not in securing advertisements.
His appeal was supported by J. E.
Richardson, the Hullabaloo's business manager. Edmond Donoho
explained a plan now employed at
Princeton, whereby all seniors who
wish to compete for the office of
cheer-leader are given an opportunity at the first games to lead the
cheering in some section of the
grandstand, the one who is most
successful being accorded the office.

One of the most famous chemists
in the world, Sir William Ramsay,
is expected to be in Baltimore next
week as the guest of Dr. and Mrs.
Remsen. Lady Ramsay is to accompany her husband. Sir William and Lady Ramsay have been
in Houston, Texas, where they attended the opening of Rice Institute. There he delivered several
lectures in connection with the exercises. Dr. Remsen and Sir William are life-long friends, having
met forty years ago at Tubingen
University, Germany. Sir William
was then a student in chemistry,
and Dr. Remsen was an assistant.
The President has entertained Sir
William in this country before, but
never in Baltimore.
To every student in chemistry,
Sir William Ramsay is a name to
conjure with. It was he who discovered the rarer gases of the
atmosphere ; who discovered helium
'in minerals, before known only to
exist in the atmosphere of the sun.
With the aid of another chemist,
he has shown that radium is transformed partially spontaneously into
helium. Sir William is one of the
recipients of the Nobel prize.
An honorary member of the
Royal Academies of Ireland, Berlin, Bohemia, Holland, Rome, St.
Petersburg, Turin, Roumania, Vienna, Norway and Sweden, Sir
William was created knight in 1902
for his chemical discoveries.
Friday afternoon at three o'clock
Sir William will receive the honorary degree of LL.D. from this University. The facultS7 will attend in
gowns, but this is as far as the
formality of the occasion will go.
Invitations to the ceremony will
be sent to the chemists of this city,
and to the members of the American Chemical Society in Washington. President Remsen has expressed the wish that there may
be a large number of students at
the exercises. This being a rare
opportunity to see one of the great
chemists of the world, every student who can possibly, do so, should
not fail to be present. After the
conferring of the degree, President
and Mrs. Remsen will give a small
reception at their home on Monument street in honor of their distinguished guests.

1916 Has Its First Meeting.

Around and About.

Lnder the direction of the Student Council the freshman class
held a meeting in Room 12 last
Wednesday to elect officers. Although in years past freshmen
were never left unmolested when
they endeavored to hold meetings
in McCoy Hall, the recently formed
body of student representatives had
the situation fully in hand this year
and no attempts were made to
"break up" the meeting.
President Short of the sophomore class stated officially before
the election took place that the
members of his class would make
no efforts to disturb it.
About forty-five freshmen were
present at the meeting. Although
this is a small number, considering
the total membership of the class, it
is a greater proportion of the total
membership than was the case
when new men had to run up and
down blind alleys to find a suitable
back yard in which to hold their
meetings.
The officers elected were:
President, Primrose; vice-president, Bagley; secretary, Tingley;
treasurer, Nelson; sergeant - at arms, Hall.
The representative of 1916 for
the Student Council is George
Penniman. .
J. S. Dickinson of the Student
Council presided.

This week, night football practice begins under the acetylene
lights. Laboratories keep so many
men in town late that the only way
to make up for the time lost is to
use the giant reflectors.
Ninety - four men are taking
Physics I under Prof. Ames. Some
of the increase is due to the "tech"
men, many of whom are required
to take the course in their freshman year.
Dirt is being moved to enlarge
the new practice field at Homewood. This ground, which lies between Hopkins Field and Charles
Street avenue, is not expected to
have sufficient turf surface for playing until next fall. All teams will
use it in practice.
Dr. Greene got there first!- The
large new apartment house almost
opposite Homewood on University
Parkway is called "Canterbury.

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 14, 1912.

6
Changes in 1912 Football Rules.

First—Playing field, formerly
yards in length, is shortened to an
even loo yards. This change in
itself is not vital, but is made in
order to make possible on small
grounds an extension on territory
in which the forward pass may be
used.
Second—A zone of 10 yards
width beyond the goal lines is established. The purpose of this is
to provide ample space for execution of the forward pass, and scoring on a pass made across the goal
line into this zone is permitted.
Third—The number of downs to
gain to yards is increased from
three to four.
Fourth—The value of touchdowns in increased from five to
six points, the goal from touchdowns and other scores standing
as at present.
Fifth—The 20-yard zone, in
which the former rules provided restrictions to interfere with the forward pass, is eliminated so that the
restrictions will apply now to any
part of the field.
Sixth—After a touch-back the
ball will be put in play from the
20-yard line instead of the 25-yard
line
Seventh—On a kick-off, the ball
instead of being put in play from
the center of the field, will be kicked
from the 4o-yard line of the team
kicking off. Taking into consideration the shortening of the field and
this change in the rules, the kick
is lengthened by 5 yards.
Eighth—The field judge is eliminated; the head linesman will hereafter keep time and be judge of
the official plays in the line of scrimmage.
Ninth—The number of men allowed on the side lines, formerly
three, is reduced to one for each
team.
Tenth—Provision is made that a
bouncing ball cannot score a legitimate goal.
Eleventh—The interval between
the first and second and the third
and fourth periods is reduced from
two minutes to one minute. .

THE PROFESSORS' VACATIONS
Where the Instructors Have Passed the
Summer Europe Very Popular.
Many Go to New England.

14

Prof. Bright spent most of his
time here and at Blue Ridge Summit. The Doctor revised one of his
books, also worked on another he
is preparing for the Carnegie Institute.
Prof. W. B. Clark went as a delegate from the University to the
two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the Royal Society in London. King George, honorary president, received the delegates and later
entertained them at Windsor. At the
closing meeting in Westminster
Abbey, speeches were made by the
Prime Minister, Lord Morley, and
the Archbishop of Canterbury. The
Royal Society is the parent from
which all other scientific societies
have sprung. This two hundred
and fiftieth anniversary was attended by the foremost scientific men
a n d educators throughout t h e
world. Many college presidents
from this country were delegates—
notably the presidents of II7trvard,
Princeton and Yale.
Prof. Clark spent the remainder
of the summer touring by automobile in England, France, Germany. Belgium and Switzerland.
Dr. Reid also toured in Europe
this past summer.
Prof. Jones was in 'Germany,
Switzerland and Holland visiting
the scientific laboratories and observing research work in progress.
He also spent some time in Munich.
Prof. Greene traveled in. Germany and Switzerland.
Prof. Wilson spent the first part
of the summer in Colorado Springs.
During August he was at the
School of American Arclreology at
Santa Fe. September found Dr.
Wilson in Southern California.
Dr. Abercrombie, during the holidays, camped on Lake Michigan
and the Maumee River. He also
visited friends in Toledo, Detroit
and Chicago.
Dr. Myers found time in the
early summer 'to do some canoeing
in New Jersey.
Dr. French was in the Adirondacks..
Dean Griffin as usual stayed at

Of the teams which Hopkins
meets the remainder of the season,
Swarthmore seems to be most formidable. 'Swarthmore beat Pennsylvania Saturday, 6 to 3, in a
game which left no doubt as to its
decisiveness. A week ago Swarthmore won from Lafayette by a
score of 30 to o; and Lafayette
held Yale down to 16 points Saturday. Swarthmore's strength, thus
compared with that of two great
football concerns, shows tip well.
The 'Varsity games with Swarthmore comes in two weeks, and
something must be done!
St. John's defeated the heavy
F. and M. team last week, but not
very much can be learned of their
team, save that it is of tremendous
weight. Saturday will be the first
time Hopkins has met this college.
On two occasions Stevens has
made poor showings this season.
Both Princeton and the Army won
from her by scores as large as 30
points. The scores of 2 to 0, reversed, respectively for the last
two years, bid fair to change their
aspect this fall, and we may look
for a decisive score at Homewood.
St. John's and Dickinson battled
to a 6 to 6 score on Saturday, in
a.game which showed little skill on
either side. St. John's still employs her fake kicks, and forward
Passes to men lurking on the side
lines, and there is a report that
they have a fair team.
Western Maryland characterized
her game with Washington College
by lack of offensive ability. Furthermore, Washington played well
and won, 13 to o.

LUCAS BROTHERS

The second meeting of the Arbitration Literary Society, which was
held last Thursday in the Donovan
Room, was addressed by Mr. J. T.
O'Neill, for several years police
justice in the Eastern District of
the city. The spontaneous applause
which greeted him after he had
finished his talk showed that he had
deeply impressed every man who
heard him. Although toward the
close of his speech he was very
serious, calling on Hopkins men to
keep the "peanut politician" from
obstructing the course of justice,
and urging them to give a helping
hand to .all persons in trouble, the
main body of his speech was illuminated by true Irish wit. He made
no attempt to philosophize, but
simply told of his experiences during the three years he was a justice,
when he handed out justice to
15,030 men, women and children,
belonging to 26 different nationalities. Of these 15,000 he dismissed
8,000, because he believed that in
each case the criminals were penitent. One Jell, in listening to Mr.
O'Neill, that if there was any man
in the world who could make the
hardest criminal repent, it was he.
One of the funniest stories the
Justice told was about a man who
wanted to get a divorce from his
wife because she would not serve
him with soup. He called the wife,
who was in Court with her husband, aside and told her to give the
man soup every day until further
notice. He then sent the couple
away telling the husband to report
every Sun-day how he was getting
along. The first Sunday the man
came in rubbing his hands and said,
delightedly: "Well, Judge, I've had
my soup—had it every day last
week." The next week, when he
came in, he said : "I've had my soup
this week," to which Justice O'Neill
replied, "I'm mighty glad of that."
The third week the man came in
and said: "Good Lord, can't you
make that woman stop giving me
soup?" The Justice then notified
the wife to stop the soup diet, and
the couple lived happily ever after.
